Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Story: It’s Sunday evening, and my phone buzzes with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” I know they expect to hear from me every week, to catch up and reassure them that I’m doing well. It’s our routine, a way to bridge the distance and the awkwardness that sometimes lingers between step-parent and step-child. I glance at my laptop, where a Slack message from QA flashes: “UI glitch on the dashboard again. Users are confused. Can you look into it?” I sigh. The bug isn’t critical—there’s a simple workaround—but I know the team expects me to be responsive, to jump in and fix things quickly. My parents want to feel included in my life, to know I care enough to call. My team wants reliability, someone who doesn’t let small issues slide. I stare at my phone, then at my laptop, feeling the pressure build in my chest. I can’t do both at once, and whichever I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
